metadata.title: Unveiling the <ce:italic>in-situ</ce:italic> formation of single-atomically dispersed Pd-Fe bimetallic catalytic sites during anisole hydrodeoxygenation

Fig. 1 The hydrodeoxygenation activity of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst for anisole to benzene. (a) the conversion of anisole and selectivity to benzene as the function of temperature. (b) the catalytic performance on the stream of time at 300 °C. The experiment conditions are described in the supporting information. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Transmission electron microscope images of the Pd/ Fe2O3 under (a-b) bright field, (c) high resolution image, (d) dark field. The element dispersive spectrum for the element mapping of (e) O, (f) Fe, (g) Pd, and (h) combination of all elements. Fig 2 Fig. 3 X-ray diffraction pattern of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst and Fe2O3. The diffraction of quartz sands which was used to dilute the catalyst is also marked by a rhombic label. The JCPDF references are PDF#87–0722 for Fe, PDF#87–1165 for Fe2O3, PDF#87–0645 for Pd, PDF#85–0621 for quartz sand (SiO2). Fig 3 Fig. 4 Surface redox property of the Fe2O3 and Pd/Fe2O3 catalysts. The temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of (a) fresh Pd/Fe2O3 and Fe2O3, (b) the Pd/Fe2O3 and Fe2O3 after HDO reaction. (c) the temperature programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) on the fresh catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 X-ray photoelectron spectrum of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst as prepared and after reaction at 300 °C. (a) Fe2p and (b) Pd3d. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The in-situ X-ray absorption spectrum of Pd K edge of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst measured under HDO reaction conditions. (a) in-situ XANES of Pd K edge, (b) Fourier transformed EXAFS of Pd K edge, (c) wavelet transformed EXAFS, (d) data fitting, (e) fitting parameters for the Pd K edge spectrum during HDO, and (f) the proposed model of Pd1Fe3 on Fe substrate. The spectra of Pd foil and PdO are plotted as references. The amplitude of FT-EXAFS of Pd foil and PdO in (b) is rescaled by 0.4 for better comparison. All the EXAFS spectra in (b-d) are demonstrated without phase correction. Fig 6 Unveiling the in-situ formation of single-atomically dispersed Pd-Fe bimetallic catalytic sites during anisole hydrodeoxygenation Shuya Zhang Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing 1 Xiaochen Liu Investigation Formal analysis 1 Hongqiao Lin Investigation Formal analysis Rong Chen Investigation Formal analysis Yu Chen Investigation Formal analysis Yuanjie Xu Investigation Formal analysis Kaiyang Xu Investigation Formal analysis Huibo Zhao Investigation Formal analysis Li Tan Formal analysis Funding acquisition Lizhi Wu Formal analysis Funding acquisition Yu Tang Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing ⁎ Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 China Institute of Molecular Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed to this work equally. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a promising route to convert biomass molecules into biofuels, which is usually promoted by supported noble metal catalysts. It is still one of the key issues to reduce the usage of noble metal for improving the atomic efficiency of the catalyst. As a type of emerging catalytic materials, single-atomically dispersed bimetallic catalyst (SDBM) is a promising candidate for this purpose. Herein, we investigated a single-atomically dispersed Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst with the exceptional HDO activity. At 573 K, anisole conversion is 99% while the selectivity to HDO products is 84%. The turnover rate per Pd atom is 182.2 h−1, which is remarkably greater than that of supported Pd nanoparticles. Additionally, it exhibits good stability for more than 110 h of continuously operation. The authentic catalytic sites during reaction was studied by comprehensive techniques. The presence of the Pd atoms on Fe2O3 changes the surface chemistries of the catalyst surface, then boosts the HDO activity consequently. As unveiled by in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, the Pd atoms are coordinated with 2.76 nearby Fe atoms in average via metallic Pd-Fe bonds. Under HDO reaction conditions, single atomically dispersed Pd1Fe3 bimetallic sites are generated in-situ and act as the authentic catalytic sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Hydrodeoxygenation Single atom catalyst Palladium In-situ X-ray absorption spectrum Data availability Data will be made available on request. Heterogeneous catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass-derived molecules is one of these promising routes to convert biomass materials to biofuels and other valuable chemicals [1,2]. The main functions of an HDO catalyst are the dissociation of molecule H2 as well as the cleavage of CO bond of the biomass molecules [3]. Therefore, transition metal elements, including noble metals (Rh, Ru, Pd, Pt, Au), have been widely investigated in past decades to understand the reaction mechanism and further optimize the HDO catalyst [4,5]. Considering the goals of sustainable chemistry and the usage of noble metal in the HDO catalyst, the high efficient utilization of noble metal atom is necessary in the catalyst design. Single atom catalyst has attracted lots of attention for bringing new opportunities to catalysis research, which is featured for the uniform atomic structure of catalytic sites and nearly 100% utilization of metal atoms [6,7]. Nevertheless, it is noticed that those noble metal elements exhibit superior activity in HDO [8]. As one kind of emerging single atom catalyst, singly dispersed bimetallic (SDBM) catalyst is composed of two metal elements (M-A) and featured for its unique structure and distinct adsorption behaviours [9–12]. Typically, the M atoms are single atomically dispersed on the surface of the AOx support without formation of continuous M-M metallic bond [9–11]. Moreover, the M atoms are coordinated with a few A atoms instead. This unique atomic structure makes SDBM a promising material for catalyst deign. So far, SDBM catalyst has demonstrated its great potential in many heterogeneous catalysis reactions including ammonia synthesis [9,13], NO reduction [10,14], CO oxidation [15], hydrogen production[16–19], Fisher-Tropsch synthesis [20], propane dehydrogenation[21] and methane conversion [22]. In this work, Pd-Fe SDBM catalytic sites are formed in-situ during HDO of anisole, and exhibits superior catalytic activity. The starting material of the catalyst, Pd/Fe2O3 material was prepared by precipitation-deposition method as described in the supporting information (SI). The catalytic activity of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst was evaluated by the HDO of anisole, a typical molecule which has been investigated as the model monomer of lignocellulose derived biomass stock [23,24]. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the HDO activity as the function of reaction temperature is shown by anisole conversion and the selectivity to HDO product, benzene. Clearly, the HDO activity depends on the reaction temperature. The optimal reaction temperature is found at 300 °C, whereas the conversion of 99% and the selectivity of 84% are obtained. As the comparison, the bare Fe2O3 support shows no HDO activity at 300 °C as shown in Fig. S1. Therefore, the HDO activity of Pd/Fe2O3 is mainly attributed to the presence of Pd on the surface of the catalyst. Nevertheless, the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst also shows a good stability on the time of stream as shown in Fig. 1b. The catalyst usage was reduced (Fig. 1b) to regulate the conversion below 90% to examine whether there is any deactivation of the catalyst on the time of stream. The conversion (84%) and selectivity (83%) remain well on the time of stream for 110 h. No significantly deactivation is observed after 110 h. Therefore, the Pd/Fe2O3 is a highly active and robust catalyst for HDO reaction. The intrinsic activity of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst was further compared with other catalysts reported in literatures for the turnover rate (TOR). Here, the TOR is defined as the molecule produced per Pd atom per hour (see the evaluation details in SI). The authentic loading concentration of Pd in the catalyst was firstly measured by induced coupled plasma optic emission spectrum (ICP-OES). The authentic Pd loading amount is 0.052 wt.% (Table S1), which was applied in the TOR calculation. Based on the Pd amount evaluated by ICP-OES, a TOR of 182.2 h−1 is obtained for Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst at 573 K. As the comparison, the TOR of supported Pd nanoparticle catalysts under similar reaction conditions in recent literatures are summarized Table S2. A typical TOR value in the range of 0.13–37.3 h−1 is reported for Pd nanoparticles on various support [25–27]. Based on the TOR comparison, the site specific activity of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst is much higher than Pd of other state reported in literatures. In other words, the Pd catalytic sites in Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst are more efficient for HDO conversion than conventional supported Pd nanoparticles. The significantly higher site specific TOR may not only benefit from the high dispersion of Pd atoms in the catalyst, but also due to the unique properties of the catalytic sites [10,11]. Therefore, it is necessary to unveil the authentic structure of catalyst at the atomic level to pursue further understanding from the aspects of redox properties, chemical state and coordination environments. The Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst was firstly examined by transmission electron microscope (TEM) to reveal the nanostructure. As shown in Fig. 2 , the TEM images of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst before reaction are demonstrated by bright field image (a-b), high resolution image (c), HAADF image (d), and energy dispersive spectrum (e-h). Generally, Fe2O3 nanoparticles are observed under bright field with the size of c.a. 10–20 nm. The lattice fringe of 2.2 Å is observed in the high resolution image, which is assigned to the distance of Fe2O3 (113) crystal plane. There is no Pd nanoparticle observed on the Fe2O3, which is further confirmed by the EDS analysis. Clearly, the Pd, Fe and O elements are dispersed evenly on the catalyst, suggesting the Pd is highly dispersed. Moreover, the catalyst after HDO reaction was also analyzed under the similar TEM protocol. As shown in Fig. S2, the catalyst after reaction still exhibits the morphology of nanoparticles. The element dispersions of Pd, Fe and O remain evenly dispersed after reaction, excluding the aggregation of Pd to form nanoparticles after HDO reaction. Thus, the Pd atoms are still highly dispersed on the support after reaction. The porosity of the catalyst before reaction was determined by N2 physical adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S3 and Table S3). The specific surface area, pore size and specific pore volume of the catalyst before and after reaction are similar, suggesting there is no major change in the nanostructure of the catalyst. Therefore, the Pd atoms in the catalyst before and after reaction are highly dispersed on support, which is in line with the TEM results. The catalyst was then examined with X-ray diffraction (XRD) to understand the crystal structure change after reaction. As shown in Fig. 3 , the XRD patterns of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst and Fe2O3 are measured before and after HDO reaction. The standard powder diffraction files (PDF) are also indicated at the bottom of Fig. 3. It is found that a typical diffraction pattern of Fe2O3 is observed in the fresh Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst. After HDO reaction at 300 °C, the diffraction patterns of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst and Fe2O3 changes obviously to the metallic Fe of face centered cubic structure. Therefore, it is concluded that the Fe2O3 support is reduced to metallic state under reaction at 300 °C. It is also noticed that the diffraction peak of metallic Pd is not observed in the XRD results, excluding the formation of large metallic Pd nanoparticles. This observation is consistent with the element mapping results in Fig. 2 and S2. Considering the reduction temperature of 300 °C for Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst is much lower than the reduction temperature of Fe2O3 [28], the presence of Pd changes the redox reactivity of the Fe2O3 support. The redox property was further investigated by temperature programed reduction for the fresh catalysts and the catalysts after HDO reaction (TPR, Fig. 4 a-b). As shown in the Fig. 4a, three reduction peaks are found at 365, 418 and 570 °C in the TPR pattern of fresh Fe2O3 catalyst, which are assigned to the reduction step from Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, to FeO, and to Fe, respectively [28]. However, the fresh Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst shows a different TPR pattern. Only one dominant peak at 230 °C is observed, indicating a significant reduction occurs at 230 °C, which is much higher than the reduction temperature of supported Pd nanoparticles but lower than that of Fe2O3 [28,29]. It is also noticed that the reduction temperature is lower than the HDO reaction temperature at 300 °C. Therefore, it is reasonable to deduce the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst was reduced to metallic during HDO reaction, which is consistent with above XRD result. The hydrogen consumed in this peak is 0.105 mmol/g, which is much higher than the reduction of Pd needed in the catalyst quantitatively (Table S4). Thus, it is proposed that the peak at 230 °C is due to the reduction of Pd with the surrounding Fe atoms, then further lead to the formation of highly dispersed PdFe bimetallic sites [30]. The TPR results of the Pd/Fe2O3 and Fe2O3 catalyst after HDO reaction show a similar pattern (Fig. 4b). Combined with above mentioned XRD results, the PdFe bimetallic sites may be formed during reaction. Nevertheless, the adsorption-desorption behavior of the catalyst is shown in H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) in Fig. 4c. The desorption peak of H2 on the fresh Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst occurs at the temperature similar to that of Fe2O3. However, the desorption amount is 0.208 mmol/g, which is much higher than that of Fe2O3 (0.060 mmol/g). Therefore, the capacity to adsorb hydrogen is greatly enhanced by addition of Pd to Fe2O3. The enhanced affinity to hydrogen over the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst is favored for the HDO reaction. Moreover, it is confirmed again that the surface of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst is fully reduced during HDO at 300 °C. The chemical state of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst was investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS). As shown in Fig. 5 a, the Fe2p feature of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst before and after reaction are similar. A major peak at 710.9 eV is observed for the Fe3+ in cationic state. However, a new minor peak is found at 706.6 eV for the catalyst after reaction. The new peak of 706.6 eV is assigned to Fe0 at metallic state [31]. The major peaks at 710.8 and 710.9 eV of Fe2p spectra suggest the surface of the catalyst after reaction is still covered by a thin oxide layer, although the bulk phase of Fe2O3 has been reduced to metallic as suggested by XRD. The surface oxide layer on bulk metallic Fe may be attributed to exposure to environmental oxygen when transferring the sample from fixed-bed reactor to the XPS chamber. Additionally, the Pd3d spectra exhibit an oxidized Pd2+ cationic state (337.2 eV) before reaction, but reduced to 335.6 eV for metallic state. The Pd3d spectra are deconvoluted as shown in Fig. 5b. The binding energy values of Pd3d5/2 are marked in the figure. After HDO reaction of anisole at 300 °C, two pairs of doublet are observed in Pd3d spectrum. The major doublet is found at 335.6 eV and 340.9 eV. Another minor doublet is found at 337.2 eV and 342.3 eV. After deconvolution, it is found that the Pd is mainly metallic Pd, and the ratio of P d 0 P d 0 + P d 2 + is 0.803. It should be noted again that the XPS measurement was performed ex-situ. The sample was exposed to air when transferring from fixed-bed reactor to XPS chamber. Therefore, the portion of oxidized Pd2+ in the Pd/Fe2O3–300 °C may be resulted by oxygen contamination during sample transferring. Thus, in the following text, in-situ XAS measurement on the Pd K edge during HDO reaction was implemented to unveil the electronic state and coordination environment of Pd. All the above results suggest that the metallic sites containing Pd and Fe may be formed during HDO reaction. However, a catalyst could undergo restructuring to form authentic catalytic active sites under reaction environment [32,33]. In this work, the formation of PdFe SDBM was confirmed by in-situ X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS). The catalyst powder was loaded in an in-situ reaction cell of capillary quartz tube to perform in-situ XAS studies [34]. As shown in Fig. 6 , the in-situ XAS spectrum of Pd K edge are demonstrated by X-ray absorption near edge spectrum (XANES), Fourier transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) and Wavelet transformed EXAFS (WT-EXAFS). The electron state of Pd in the catalyst during HDO is clearly shown by XANES in Fig. 6a. The energy of the absorption edge is very close to that of Pd foil, while the post-edge oscillations are also similar to Pd foil but the amplitude is weaker. Thus, the electronic state of Pd during HDO reaction is very close, and consequently assigned to metallic. Moreover, there is only one major peak observed in the FT-EXAFS of Pd K edge during HDO (Fig. 6b, all EXAFS spectra are presented without phase correction). This peak shows up in the radial distance of c.a. 2.0 Å in the FT-EXAFS plot, which cannot be identified as Pd-O or Pd-Pd pathway in PdO and Pd foil, respectively. Based on XRD, TPR, XPS, in-situ XANES results, this pathway is interpreted as Pd-Fe coordination pathway [35]. This Pd-Fe coordination pathway of SDBM structure was further confirmed by the wavelet transformed (WT) analysis of in-situ EXAFS spectra. The main purpose of WT analysis is to distinguish the element of coordination atoms at the same shell since the k value of maximum in the WT plot depends on the atomic number of coordination atoms [15,20–22,36,37]. Thus, it could distinguish elements such as Pd and Fe at the similar coordination shell. As shown in Fig. 6c, the center of the maximum in the contour plot of Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst shows a k value of 7.8 Å, while the k value of Pd-Pd coordination of Pd foil is 10.1 Å. It is due to coordination with an element lighter than Pd. Therefore, the signal of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst could be excluded from Pd-Pd coordination pathway. As the conclusion, the Pd-Fe pathway is solid confirmed based on the FT-EXAFS and WT-EXAFS analysis. The EXAFS data was further fitted with the model of Pd-Fe coordination path. The fitting result of the r -space and k-space is demonstrated in the Figs. 6d and S4, respectively. The coordination number (CN) of Pd-Fe bond is 2.76, suggesting every Pd atom is coordinated with 2.76 Fe atoms in average. The in-situ formation of singly dispersed Pd1Fe3 bimetallic structure is proposed on the surface of support (Fig. 6f). Iron oxide surface has been considered as an active catalyst for HDO at the higher temperature, but would be deactivated due to bond with oxygen atoms to form oxide layers even under H2 atmosphere [38–41]. As revealed in this work, the role of in-situ formed Pd1Fe3 SDBM sites is to improve the resistance to oxidation of the surface of catalyst as evidenced by the in-situ XAS and H2-TPR. Nevertheless, the Pd1Fe3 SDBM sites utilize the H2 more efficiently under mild temperature (H2-TPR in Fig. 4a-b), and has a larger capacity to adsorb H2 (H2-TPD in Fig. 4c). Tao and Wang et al. investigated the surface structure of Fe-based catalysts during HDO reaction [40]. They found that surface Fe species was not oxidized in Pd-Fe catalyst, as confirmed by AP-XPS. Additionally, they also observed that the addition of Pd can stabilize the metallic Fe surface. In this work, the H2-TPR and H2-TPD results suggest that the Pd1Fe3 SDBM sites promote the hydrogen dissociation and make the catalyst surface more easily to maintain the reduced state, which may be the origination of the unique activity by Pd1Fe3 sites. Therefore, the superior catalytic activity and stability benefit from the unique redox feature of PdFe SDBM sites. In summary, the Pd1Fe3 singly dispersed bimetallic catalyst is in-situ formed during hydrodeoxygenation of anisole as identified by in-situ XAS and other complimentary characterizations. It shows an outstanding catalytic performance by the high turnover rate and excellent stability with a minimum usage of noble metal Pd. The unique adsorption and redox properties of the Pd1Fe3 SDBM catalyst attribute to the outstanding catalytic performance. This work demonstrates the potential of SDBM catalyst for the sustainable chemistry and green chemistry. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a promising route to convert biomass molecules into biofuels, which is usually promoted by supported noble metal catalysts. It is still one of the key issues to reduce the usage of noble metal for improving the atomic efficiency of the catalyst. As a type of emerging catalytic materials, single-atomically dispersed bimetallic catalyst (SDBM) is a promising candidate for this purpose. Herein, we investigated a single-atomically dispersed Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst with the exceptional HDO activity. At 573 K, anisole conversion is 99% while the selectivity to HDO products is 84%. The turnover rate per Pd atom is 182.2 h−1, which is remarkably greater than that of supported Pd nanoparticles. Additionally, it exhibits good stability for more than 110 h of continuously operation. The authentic catalytic sites during reaction was studied by comprehensive techniques. The presence of the Pd atoms on Fe2O3 changes the surface chemistries of the catalyst surface, then boosts the HDO activity consequently. As unveiled by in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy, the Pd atoms are coordinated with 2.76 nearby Fe atoms in average via metallic Pd-Fe bonds. Under HDO reaction conditions, single atomically dispersed Pd1Fe3 bimetallic sites are generated in-situ and act as the authentic catalytic sites.
coredata.dc:title: Unveiling the in-situ formation of single-atomically dispersed Pd-Fe bimetallic catalytic sites during anisole hydrodeoxygenation
